title: How to Refill an Inkjet Printer Cartridge: Step-by-Step Guide

steps.title: Buy an ink refill kit for your printer.
steps.content: Buy an ink refill kit for your printer. Many office supply, discount, and department stores carry these kits for a fraction of the cost of an official replacement cartridge. [1] X Research source Kits usually come with everything you need to refill an existing cartridge, including ink, a syringe, seal covers, a manual, and a screw tool. Some ink refill kits are universal, meaning they are intended to work for all inkjet printer brands. Others are manufacturer or model-specific. Most printer companies advise against refilling your own printer ink. Instead, they recommend that you purchase new cartridges from them directly. Refilling your own cartridges may void your ability to receive tech support from the printer manufacturer, so refill at your own risk. Some major retailers like Walgreens and Costco will refill empty ink cartridges for you.

steps.title: Prepare your workspace.
steps.content: Prepare your workspace. Ink can be messy, so lay down some newspaper or paper towels on a flat working surface. [2] X Research source Then, grab your ink kit, more paper towels, a pair of gloves you don't mind getting dirty, some clear tape, and safety glasses. Printer ink will leave permanent stains on clothing and surfaces. Put on gloves to protect your hands. Though ink stains on your skin won't be permanent, they can definitely stick around a long time. Wear safety glasses to protect your eyes. In the event that ink sprays excessively, safety glasses will prevent the ink from getting in your eyes.

steps.title: Remove the printer cartridge.
steps.content: Remove the printer cartridge. The steps to do this vary by printer, but the cartridges are usually not too difficult to remove. You may need to turn the printer on so the cartridges move to an accessible location. Check your printer's manual to find the exact location of the cartridges and the steps for removal.

steps.title: Place the empty cartridge on a folded paper towel.
steps.content: Place the empty cartridge on a folded paper towel. Fold the paper towel in half twice to make an effective spill guard to work over.

steps.title: Read the refill kit's instruction manual.
steps.content: Read the refill kit's instruction manual. The manual will contain instructions specific to the kit, including information on how to use included tools. If the manual's instructions differ much from this wikiHow, stick to the manual's instructions.

steps.title: Find the ink fill hole on the cartridge.
steps.content: Find the ink fill hole on the cartridge. Some cartridges, such as those made by HP, already have a fill hole that doesn't require you to puncture the cartridge. [3] X Research source Peel back the label from the top of the cartridge to find potential fill holes. If you're working with a cartridge that has multiple inks in a single unit, each color will have its own fill hole. If you find more than one hole, only one actually leads to the ink reservoir. Inspect each hole until you find one with a spongy material inside—this is the fill hole. You can verify by attempting to remove some existing ink with the syringe included in the kit. Some manufacturers place a twist-off cap on each cartridge that must be removed to expose the fill hole. If the fill hole is sealed, you'll just need to break the seal to fill it.

steps.title: Create a fill hole in the absence of one.
steps.content: Create a fill hole in the absence of one. If there is no fill hole on the cartridge (or the hole is covered with a seal), you'll need to puncture the plastic to create one yourself. The best way to do this is to use the screw tool or drill bit that came with your kit to pierce the top side of the cartridge. If your kit didn't come with a puncture tool, try a pen, toothpick, knife, or screwdriver. If you're filling one multicolor cartridge, you'll need to do this for each color. Be sure to follow any instructions in the kit that describe proper hole-making and placement.

steps.title: Fill the syringe with ink.
steps.content: Fill the syringe with ink. Begin by pressing the syringe's plunger all the way in. Insert the long end into the replacement ink bottle and slowly pull the plunger away to fill the chamber with ink.

steps.title: Add the ink to the cartridge slowly.
steps.content: Add the ink to the cartridge slowly. Insert the long end of the syringe into the fill hole on the cartridge until you hit the spongy bottom. Then, gently push the plunger down to add ink. Push slowly to avoid adding air bubbles, as they can break the cartridge.

steps.title: Stop adding ink when a little oozes out of the hole.
steps.content: Stop adding ink when a little oozes out of the hole. This means you've reached the top. At this point, pull the plunger outward just a bit to suck out some of the excess ink, then remove the syringe from the fill hole. Clean the area around the fill hole with a paper towel. You'll want this area free of ink and dry before you plug it up

steps.title: Cover the hole with a small piece of tape.
steps.content: Cover the hole with a small piece of tape. If your kit came with a seal/stopper that fits into the hole, you can insert it now. Sometimes tape creates a better seal, though. Once sealed, blot the top of the cartridge on the folded paper towel a few times to clear off any excess ink. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Fill additional colors.
steps.content: Fill additional colors. If your kit came with more than one syringe, use a different one for each color to avoid mixing colors together. If not, thoroughly wash and dry your syringe between colors. Be sure to blot all excess ink off each cartridge before putting them back into the printer.

steps.title: Reinsert the cartridge(s) and print a test page.
steps.content: Reinsert the cartridge(s) and print a test page. After putting the cartridge back in the printer, print something to get the ink flowing. If you refilled multiple colors, print something in both full-color and black-and-white to make sure all of the ink prints properly. You may need to print several test pages to get everything flowing properly. You’re done! You’ve successfully refilled your ink cartridges. Next, check out how to save printer ink . If the papers seem to be smudging ink, try cleaning the ink cartridges .
